awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Pervasive Spectrum Sharing for Public Safety Communications
awd_abstract_narration:
Next-generation public safety communication (PSC) systems must deliver high-capacity wireless services to public safety personnel and users in disaster-affected areas, with little reliance on infrastructure. Remarkably, modern-day PSC systems have yet to catch up with the past decade's wireless revolution, as they still rely on technologies of yesteryears that fall short on delivering high-speed wireless access. Indeed, coping with the foreseen stringent service requirements in future PSC systems mandates major innovations that can increase spectral efficiency. This, in turn, requires tackling multidisciplinary challenges: 1) developing incentive mechanisms for government agencies, providers, and users to share their precious spectrum resources; 2) dynamically managing interdependent spectrum markets; and 3) efficiently modeling and operating sustainable communication protocols that can function with little infrastructure support. This project brings together researchers in wireless communications and networking, game theory, mathematics, and public safety administration to address these challenges and boost the efficiency of PSC by introducing a novel framework that provides the necessary analytical tools for modeling, designing, analyzing, and operating large-scale spectrum sharing in disaster and emergency situations. 

The overarching scientific merit of this research is to initiate the much-needed leap towards a more open, highly participatory, and pervasive sharing of the wireless spectrum for PSC. This project offers an array of spectrum sharing innovations: 1) new economic approaches and PSC mechanisms that provide incentives for government agencies, providers, and end-users, to effectively subsidize the scarce radio spectrum and facilitate novel public safety and spectrum allocation policies; 2) a foundational framework that tightly integrates tools from game theory and auction theory for enabling a dynamic operation of co-existing spectrum sharing markets with multi-hop capabilities; 3) novel realistic models for characterizing wireless channels, traffic, topology, user behavior, and mobility in PSC; and 4) effective and accelerated transition of theoretical results to practice via a new PSC testbed for extensive validation and close collaboration with several major industry partners and local public safety agencies. In a nutshell, the project provides a new generation of PSC systems and protocols that expedite the response to disasters, save lives, and reduce economic costs.

por.por_cntn:
Next-generation public safety communication (PSC) systems must deliver high-capacity wireless services to public safety personnel and users in disaster-affected areas, with little reliance on infrastructure. Remarkably, modern-day PSC systems have yet to catch up with the past decade's wireless revolution, as they still rely on technologies that fall short on delivering high-speed wireless access. Indeed, coping with the foreseen stringent service requirements in future PSC systems mandates major innovations that can increase spectral efficiency. This research brought together researchers in wireless communications and networking, game theory, mathematics, and public safety administration to innovate and boost the efficiency of PSC by introducing a novel framework that provides the necessary analytical tools for modeling, designing, analyzing, and operating large-scale spectrum sharing in disaster and emergency situations. 

The scientific merit of this research is centered around the much-needed leap towards a more open, highly participatory, and pervasive sharing of the wireless spectrum for PSC. This research developed transformative techniques for managing and sharing wireless spectrum resources under various PSC scenarios. In particular, this project introduced a framework for incentivizing cellular operators at a primary level. The framework goes beyond the existing secondary level spectrum sharing approaches that considers the use of spectral resources when their primary users are idle, and incentivizes operators to share their spectrum and infrastructure resources with foreign users (i.e., users subscribed to another provider) even if their own users may not be idle. To attain such incentives, the project explored subsidy-based and reward-based market models, and outlined stable and efficient operational regimes under these spectrum market models. In order to address potential freeriding issues in co-primary spectrum markets, the project resulted in game-theoretic models to study the interactions between a large provider that is sharing its spectrum resources and small providers that may be interested in freeriding on the large provider's resources. Coupled with these spectrum management approaches, this research also developed economic incentive mechanisms along with public policy recommendations to promote a more pervasive sharing of wireless connectivity. The project provided advances to multiple fields that include wireless communication, game theory, optimization theory, and economics. Collectively, the results of this project provide a holistic understanding of how one can provide wireless connectivity to public safety scenarios while ensuring an effective use of the precious wireless spectrum.

The broader impacts of the project included providing awareness to the community on the importance of spectrum sharing, through tutorials, workshops, and outreach events. The spectrum market models and management techniques developed in this research have a great potential to positively impact the way we utilize the wireless spectrum, which is a precious natural resource of increasing scarcity. Increased spectrum efficiency is crucial to realizing a number of emerging applications beyond public safety, including but not limited to smart city applications, autonomous vehicles, and smart residential and commercial buildings. New curriculum material was also developed to train undergraduates and graduate students on various facets of wireless networking. The project trained several graduate and undergraduate students in advanced wireless research and resulted in doctoral and masters degrees in national priority technology areas.
